metadata.case_name: Uttar Pradesh State Warehousing Corporation v. Respondent

facts.text: Respondent-plaintiff entered service with appellant as Technical Assistant in November 1958.
Respondent promoted to post of Warehouseman on October 15, 1959.
Respondent confirmed in post of Warehouseman in 1962.
Certain charges framed against respondent; pending enquiry, placed under suspension on September 9, 1963.
After enquiry, respondent found guilty and dismissed from service by order dated March 10, 1964.

Respondent instituted Civil Suit No. 201 of 1964 challenging dismissal order as vague allegations, no proper enquiry, contrary to principles of natural justice, disregard of cl. 16 of Regulations, claimed protection under Art. 311.
Appellant in written statement pleaded enquiry proper, compliant with Regulations, full opportunity given, no Art. 311 protection, dismissal justified.

Trial Court held no Art. 311 protection, but enquiry violated sub-cl. 3 of cl. 16 of Regulations and natural justice; dismissal illegal but no reinstatement due to s. 21 Specific Relief Act 1877; granted declaration that dismissal order void, dated March 24, 1965.
Appellant appealed to Civil Judge, Manipuri in Civil Appeal No. 69 of 1965; respondent filed cross-objections for reinstatement.
Civil Judge dismissed appeal, allowed cross-objections, decreed suit granting declaration and reinstatement with full pay, dated September 4, 1965.

Appellant appealed to Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4275 of 1965; High Court dismissed appeal on October 25, 1966, upheld both reliefs, finding enquiry vitiated by violation of natural justice and Reg. 16(3), Regulations have statutory force.

Enquiry Officer Sri A. Abbasi admitted no evidence taken, considered records sufficient, collected information from police and others behind respondent's back, not put to respondent, no opportunity to cross-examine or defend.
Suspension order dated November 9, 1963 directed subsistence allowance.

legal_issues.text: Whether the enquiry was conducted in accordance with sub-cl. 3 of Regulation 16 and principles of natural justice.
Whether respondent entitled to declaration of reinstatement with full pay despite violation, or only damages, given contract of personal service.
Whether Regulations framed under s.54 of the Act have statutory force imposing mandatory obligation such that violation renders dismissal a nullity entitling continuity of service.

petitioner_arguments.text: Full and fair opportunity given in enquiry; no violation of Regulation 16(3); findings by courts erroneous.
Even if enquiry vitiated, no reinstatement as specific performance of personal service contract not enforceable; no special circumstances; remedy is damages.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.21 Specific Relief Act 1877; common law master-servant

petitioner_arguments.text: Regulations under s.54 not creating mandatory statutory obligation; breach makes dismissal wrongful, not nullity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Agricultural Produce Development and Warehousing Corporations Act, 1956 s.54

respondent_arguments.text: Enquiry not in accordance with Regulation 16(3), violation of natural justice; concurrent findings by all courts supported by evidence.
Regulations under s.54 have statutory force, mandatory; violation entitles declaration of nullity and reinstatement.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Agricultural Produce Development and Warehousing Corporations Act, 1956 s.54; Life Insurance Corporation v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee

respondent_arguments.text: Arbitrary and mala fide termination; special circumstances justify departure from normal rule.

court_reasoning.text: All courts concurrently held no Art. 311 protection; enquiry violated Reg. 16(3) as Enquiry Officer collected info behind back, no opportunity to cross-examine or defend; admissions by EO justify finding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enquiry vitiated; not under Reg. 11 as disciplinary with stigma and suspension under Ch. IV.

court_reasoning.text: Normal rule: no specific performance of personal service contract; exceptions for public servant under Art.311, industrial law, or statutory body breaching mandatory statutory obligation making order nullity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Case not under exceptions; Regulations under s.54 lay terms of service but breach not statutory nullity.

court_reasoning.text: Vine case distinguished: statutory status and nullity due to lack of power; Barber, Francis applied normal rule; Dr. Dutt no statutory nullity; Tewari exceptions not applicable; LIC case statutory under s.11 Insurance Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Violation of Reg.16(3) makes dismissal wrongful, liable for damages, not nullity continuing service.

holdings.text: Enquiry violated Regulation 16(3) and natural justice; dismissal order illegal.
No declaration for reinstatement with full pay; violates rule against specific performance of personal service; Regulations breach not statutory nullity.
Regulations under s.54 have force of terms of service but not mandatory statutory obligation rendering violation a nullity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vine v. National Dock Labour Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Declaration for continuity where statutory status and nullity due to lack of power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Barber v. Manchester Regional Hospital Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Normal master-servant; no declaration, only damages despite procedural violation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Francis v. Municipal Councillors of Kuala Lumpur
precedents_cited.relevance: No declaration for continuity absent special circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. S.B. Dutt v. University of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: No enforcement of personal service; declaration would enforce contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.R. Tewari v. District Board, Agra
precedents_cited.relevance: Exceptions to no-enforcement rule: Art.311, industrial law, statutory breach.

precedents_cited.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory rights under Insurance Act s.11; violation nullity.

precedents_cited.case_name: High Commissioner for India v. I.M. Lall
precedents_cited.relevance: Declaration of statutory invalidity, not enforcing contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Babu Ram Upadhya

precedents_cited.relevance: Breach of standing orders as statutory nullity under industrial law.

statutes_cited.name: Agricultural Produce (Development and Warehousing) Corporations Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Establishes Corporation, empowers regulations under s.54; Regulations framed thereunder.

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh State Warehousing Corporation Regulations, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Disciplinary procedure; mandatory opportunity before major punishment.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act, 1877
statutes_cited.relevance: No specific performance of personal service contracts.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld finding that enquiry violated Reg.16(3) making dismissal illegal, but set aside High Court decree granting reinstatement with full pay, holding it unenforceable as specific performance of personal service; respondent entitled only to damages if claimed.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that dismissal void (upheld); no reinstatement.

key_quotes.text: No punishment other than that specified in sub-para (1)(a), (1)(b) or (1)(c) shall be imposed on any employee without giving him an opportunity for tendering an explanation in writing and cross examining the witnesses against him, if any, and of producing evidence in defence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Reg.16(3), central to violation finding.

key_quotes.text: A contract for personal service will not be enforced by an order for specific performance nor will it be open for a servant to refuse to accept the repudiation of a contract of service by his master and say that the contract has never been terminated.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The jurisdiction to declare the decision of the Board as ultra vires exists, though it may be exercised only when the Court is satisfied that departure is called for from the rule that a contract of service will not ordinarily be specifically enforced.
key_quotes.speaker: court
